security: Several memos discuss LICOOKY/1's (Joyce H. PINEINCH) relationship with the CIA, including her termination in Mexico and subsequent re-engagement. One memo explicitly states LICOOKY/1’s fears of compromise and distaste for WOFIRM: “fear of compromise -- LICCOKY/1 said that were her relationship with us to become known, it would ruin her standing in and associations with the intellectual community; distaste for WOFIRM -- LICCORY/1 really believes that WOFIRM is a large card file with all the cards aaving errors on them.” Disclosing these details could reveal sensitive operational methods and compromise sources.
summary: This collection of documents pertains to Joyce H. PINEINCH (LICOOKY/1), detailing her engagements, tax information, performance evaluations, and eventual termination of contact with the CIA, citing issues related to emotional stability, financial incentives, and intellectual honesty.
summary_one_paragraph: This compilation of documents, dated between 1962 and 1975, centers on the CIA's relationship with Joyce H. PINEINCH, codenamed LICOOKY/1, and covers aspects such as her initial engagement as an independent contractor in Mexico City, adjustments to her contract regarding income taxes, periodic performance reviews including contacts with individuals like John GERASSI and Tana de GAMEZ, a restricted CI/CA folder on the subject, and the ultimate amicable termination of her relationship with the CIA in April 1968, driven by her fear of exposure, distaste for the agency, concerns about intellectual honesty, and a perceived lack of understanding from the CIA (WOFIRM) regarding her unique perspectives.
title: Review of 201 File on U.S. Citizen: Joyce H. PINEINCH (LICOOKY/1)
sender: Various (Chief of Base, New York; Chief, Domestic Operations Division; W. J. Kaufman; John F. Patton; Lee Peterson; Jessica T. LABATT; Howard G. FIGALAN )
